subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
We will be exploring possession today.
My guest is Adam Crabtree, who is a trainer
of psychotherapists at the Center for Training
in Psychotherapy in Toronto, Canada.
He is the author of many books, including Multiple Man Explorations in Possession and
Multiple Personality.
Other titles include his most recent book, Evolutionary Love and the Ravages of Greed.
Another book title is From Mesmer to Freud –
Magnetic Sleep and the Roots of Psychological
Healing.
In addition, he is the co-author of a wonderful
anthology called Irreducible Mind and is the
co-editor of another interesting anthology called Beyond Physicalism.
Also, with reference to this interview, Adam
was an ordained priest prior to becoming a
psychotherapist.
Welcome, Adam.
Thank you very much.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
I'm glad to be here.
As an ordained priest, you were indoctrinated
into the Catholic concepts of possession and
exorcism.
Yes.
When you're studying for ordination, you have to learn about those.
Most priests never practice or never have
the occasion to use exorcism, but you do need
to know about it and be able to do it if it be required, I suppose.
That's a very rare circumstance.
Very rare circumstance, yes.
I was a member of a Benedictine monastery,
and only one person that I knew who ever did
exorcisms in that monastery.
So there was only one, and that's a very extraordinary
thing that a person actually carries it out.
Well, I guess it's fair to say, though, that
in earlier centuries, in medieval times, for
example, exorcism would have been the standard procedure for mental illness.
I think very often it was used in those cases
where a person was acting strangely, not like
themselves, and so the assumption is that they're possessed.
Yes.
It's a controversial thing today in the Catholic
Church, a great hesitation to use these rites
because sometimes they've been used to the detriment of people who are mentally ill.
And so, rightly so, there's caution.
I mean, today it's largely considered a form of ignorant superstition.
Generally, I would say, but in the Church,
there are still people who believe that this
has a place.
Right.
In our society as well.
I hear from people all the time who accuse
those of us engaged in parapsychology of doing
the work of the devil.
Yes, right.
That's true.
That's true.
Yes.
So, as a psychotherapist, there is a need, I
suppose, to make a distinction between intrapsychic
processes that might be mistaken for possession
and the possibility of autonomous psychic
entities that literally do possess a human being.
Yes.
I think that the psychotherapist has to take
the attitude, unless proven otherwise, it's
probably a psychodynamic thing, that is, something
that's produced by intrapsychic problems,
conflicts and manifesting in that particular form.
I think that's the best assumption to make.
But I think, on the other hand, psychotherapists
should always be open to facts or to experiences
and not too quick to jump to conclusions that
are explanatory before you really know for
sure what you're dealing with.
And when you look at possession, which you
regard as an authentic phenomenon, you notice
that there are different kinds, for example,
willing possession versus unwelcomed possession.
Yes.
And historically, too, there have been a lot
of, and today still, many people who practice
possession, they want to be possessed in order
to bring messages or to accomplish services
for the community, that sort of thing.
Shamans.
That's right.
Transmediums.
Yes.
Exactly.
And that's something that is operating in our
society today, that is willing possession.
Unwilling possession is a different matter.
That's something that it might happen, I suppose,
and I don't know that much about other societies
where that could occur, but in our society,
unwilling possession would be considered something
like if you are a believer in the devil, that you might be possessed by the devil.
If you think there are demons, you might be
possessed by demons, and those would ordinarily
be considered unwilling possession.
But in many cases, it might simply be an intra-psychic process.
A person can, I suppose, become possessed by their own thoughts.
Well, yes.
That's right.
They used to call them thought forms, and
sort of take a substantial form of their own
and a life of their own.
That is, that's what the theosophists call them.
But you can be possessed by your own thoughts
just from a psychological point of view, and
that's sort of the notion of obsession.
Obsession is where a thought becomes something
that's somewhat autonomous and takes its own
actions.
Yeah.
In some of the spiritual literature, there's
the notion of the tulpa in Tibetan culture,
where a person can generate a thought form
so intensely that that thought form can take
a physical manifestation and kind of an autonomous existence.
That's right.
Yes.
There have been things written about that.
I have no direct experience of that sort of thing.
My experience has been totally through my
work as a psychotherapist, so there are other
kinds of manifestations that I've had no direct contact with.
Well, it's a big world out there, I guess.
Let's talk about some of your personal experiences with possession as a therapist.
Right.
Well, I first began becoming aware of possession,
that people were experiencing something that
looked like possession.
Let me call it that, because I don't want
to make any pronunciations of a general kind
about this very difficult topic.
Working with people who were experiencing something that looked and felt to them like
possession.
My first contact with that was in the late 70s, and as a matter of fact, it's through
that experience that I began wondering about
the adequacy of some of our psychological
and psychodynamic explanations for things, because I couldn't find a way to deal with
some of these situations.
It seemed to make sense in terms of what they were actually experiencing.
So I had to do a lot of research in the process
of coming to terms with trying to help people
who were experiencing, let me say, ostensible possession.
How did it manifest?
Well, it typically, in my practice, manifested
as an individual becoming aware of the presence
within themselves of someone that they knew about.
That is, it might have been an ancestor, that is, maybe a grandfather, grandmother.
It might have been a dead brother.
Some actual person who had been living and who had died and now seemed to be with them
and seemed to be affecting their thoughts, and this was upsetting to them.
There were some cases, also a few, where the
person was still living and yet seemed to
be with them and affecting them in a similar way.
Well, I certainly know that there are cases,
in fact the classic book in the early years
of psychical research was called Phantasms of the Living, in which living individuals
seem to manifest apparitions of themselves that
would be seen sometimes by multiple persons
in other distant locations.
Yes, yes, that's right, phantasms of the living.
In one case of this kind, this individual
that I was working with was dealing with her
mother who she felt was in her and affecting
her and she couldn't get rid of that.
Now, you can certainly look at that psychodynamically
and say this is a mother complex and so forth.
That's a legitimate way to look at it.
But it might have been both.
It might have been both.
The thing is that she did a lot of work with
her mother complex and it didn't have any
effect on this.
So she wanted to see if it could be explored
at some actual presence of her mother and
we did and her mother was still alive.
Now, the interesting thing is that when she
had a breakthrough and freed herself of this
influence from her mother, her mother who lived 500 miles away showed a big change in
her attitude and her communications with her
daughter happened simultaneously with the
end of that therapy, which is an interesting thing.
Yes, indeed.
It has maybe some bearing on how you might judge what was going on there.
But that is the sort of thing that I've seen happen.
Well, I gather that as a psychotherapist you've
never seen anything akin to what might be
called demonic possession.
No, the nearest to that was a man that I worked
with, I talk about this in the book, a man
that I worked with who felt himself possessed
by this something or other that caused him
to feel quite murderous towards his wife.
And so this was a situation where he was quite
afraid of himself in a certain way because
of that.
So we set up a project where I and a number
of people that he knew, some strong men, went
away to a kind of retreat house and worked with this thing.
And it turned out to present itself or to claim that it was a being that had existed
hundreds of years ago and had come down
through his family to him, ended up with him.
And as we continued to examine this thing and listen to it talk and explain itself,
it seemed to be something that was not human,
came from another kind of dimension or something
like that, and had gotten lost and ended up
on earth and in this particular family tree.
Now, it seemed really bizarre to me, but that was what was showing itself.
That was the narrative.
That was the narrative.
And we worked with it that way.
And eventually, in communicating with it through
talking with this man, and this is always
done in trance states, talking with the man and talking directly to it in that sense,
it began to remember where it actually came from.
Before that, it was like it had an amnesia for that.
And when it did, it realized, because it tried
to present itself as very evil and very bad,
when it did, it became much more balanced, not just this evil thing, and it seemed to
have a kind of conversion or change and left.
The outcome of the work that I have done with
possession has always been to help the entity,
person, or whoever it is, to leave and go where
they should be rather than here, bothering
this person.
Now, I know you're familiar with the work of William Baldwin, who developed what he
called the spirit-releasement therapy, sometimes known as depossession therapy.
Yes, yes, I am.
What I did was very different from that, because
first of all, he tended to see possession
as demons of various kinds, of various powers and
so forth, and his work was a kind of exorcism.
And he was quite convinced of his view, and so when he did that work, the procedure was
precisely to get rid of these things, sometimes
in the hundreds or thousands from an individual.
My work was never like that.
It was always a very individual thing.
There was a history there that had to be
understood and a resolution that had to be met.
And now let's talk about some of the more
willing forms of possession, because I think
in order to understand possession, we have
to look at the evidence for it in the annals
of psychical research, where transmediums manifest deceased persons, and often with
very clear statements that the medium herself or himself could not have known.
Yes, that's right.
Those certainly, there are many instances of those kinds.
Some of them are more convincing than others
in terms of having evidential quality.
That is, it might convince you that yes, this is that person.
I think those, for me, that are really convincing are very few.
It's possible to understand them a different
way, not saying that they aren't what they
say, but they're not really necessarily evidential and convincing.
Well, I know there's a big controversy within
parapsychology as to whether the medium is
actually possessed by the spirit of a deceased
person, or whether the medium is using some
form of extrasensory perception to gain that information.
Yes, and Stephen Braude's work on this has been very important.
I write a little bit about this in the book that I was the co-author of, Your Reducible
Mind, a very short segment in there, where I talk about one possible understanding of
what's happening is that the medium does take
in a great deal of information, and they have
an inner kind of malleability to form that into a personality.
And it would take a very special person to
be able to do that and to make it convincing.
I know William James wrote about this, the
great American psychologist, and he described
it as I recall as two wills, the will to personate
of the medium, or to incorporate that being,
and then the external will of some entity, a spiritual entity, to be personated by the
medium.
So it requires kind of a partnership.
Yes, that's the way it seemed to be, that
both are willing and that the medium has some
special ability to actually receive
communication about what needs to be passed on.
I myself don't have a theory about that.
Well, have you, in your therapy practice, addressed cases of deceased individuals?
Oh, yes.
Most of them were deceased individuals, and
most of those were relatives, related by blood,
in some way or other.
And there was a history there to be understood.
They were there not by accident, but for a reason, not necessarily that they intended
to be there within this individual affecting them.
But there was a reason for it.
Maybe they found out in the process of our work
together why they were there, they misunderstood
a situation, and once they found out, they could leave.
And so as I mentioned, the idea was always to
have enlightenment occur, some misunderstanding
dealt with so that the person could leave.
Because I would think if I'm a deceased individual
and I'm possessing a living relative for one
reason or another, it might be to my benefit to move on.
Exactly.
Well, that's what, in virtually all the cases
that I worked with, that is what happened.
They didn't realize what they were doing.
They didn't necessarily even realize they were taking possession or at least having
some influence upon this individual.
And once they realized that, they could come
to see that they really should be elsewhere.
And then they could discover where that elsewhere was and leave.
Now, all of this implies, if we're to take it literally, the existence of some sort of
a realm.
You could call it a realm of the subconscious
or you could call it a spiritual realm, and
maybe there's an overlap there, but a realm
in which the subconscious mind of human beings
such as ourselves is actually interfacing with humans who no longer are in a physical
body.
Yes.
And I think that the psychology or the vision
of Frederick Myers has a good framework for
understanding it that way.
He believed that mediums used the same channels
for gathering and expressing their information
that they used when expressing something that's interpsychic to them.
It's very the same thing.
So it's hard to judge which is which.
You have to find evidence that there's an outside source of information to prove that
that is the case.
That's right, which is tricky.
Yeah, very tricky.
But the title of the book that you co-authored,
Irreducible Mind, suggests by the very nature
that you subscribe to the idea that there is a mental realm that cannot be reduced to
physics or physiology or any form of materialism.
Yes, that's right.
And I think that that is the thing that got lost, that was being discovered.
And so there was initial explorations occurring
in the late 1800s and 1890s with James, with
Myers and others.
They were starting to explore this.
And James said, this is the problem that the
20th century should take up now, what Myers
has opened up and the questions he's brought.
And nothing was done in the 20th century.
This is why we decided, Ed Kelly was the idea, and he was the main author.
We decided that that exploration should be happening now.
It was in abeyance for the 20th century, for
a whole century, for various sociological
and psychological reasons.
Well, psychology was in effect captured by the behaviorist movement.
That's right.
The cognitive side of things also took over,
and there was quite a narrow view of the human
psyche.
So that's the idea of the book, is to say, okay, here's the problem we should take a
look at now in the 21st century, because the
subtitle of the book is, It's Irreducible
Mind Towards a Psychology for the 21st Century.
Missed the 20th.
And so that's what we tried to do.
In other words, one might say that it's time
for psychology and for society as general
to take a second look at ideas that have been
dismissed as pure superstition or animistic
thinking that have no place in the modern world.
That's right.
And one of the things that has to happen to do that is not to have preconceived notions
of what is and is not possible based on an unconsciously held, rigidly held philosophy
or metaphysics.
This can't happen, therefore you can't see it if it is happening, because you will be
censoring what you're seeing.
You will be giving it a form that's not just presenting itself to you.
This is why I believe that we are at a time when the notion of phenomenology, where we
let reality speak to us and try not to distort
it in our perception of it, is so important.
And as a psychotherapist, I imagine that you
are trained and train others to accept the
narrative that is being presented to you without judging it.
I wish I could say that.
I think that theoretically everyone would
say that, but in fact, when you start setting
up psychological systems, you start forming
ideas of what you're going to be looking for,
and you miss other things, unfortunately.
So I think the great struggle for the psychotherapist
is not to do that, to really just let things
present themselves to you without judgment, even though you say, how is that or that's
weird, without judgment.
Because then you can take in the whole of the evidence or the facts that are coming
to you.
And certainly, many people have very strong opinions about these things.
Right.
That's true.
There are certainly going to be people, and I get comments from viewers occasionally,
who will watch an interview like this and post a comment saying, this is all BS.
Right.
Right.
Which is highly judgmental.
Well, it is, and that person or whoever needs to say, why do you say that?
Maybe you're right, but what is the reason?
Is it just your assumption?
Is this something you were taught?
Is this something that seemed inevitable to you because of what other people said?
Or is this something you've really looked into and really put aside prejudice to see
what is and isn't possible in fact?
Well, once again, Adam Crabtree, a fascinating
discussion of an issue that may be of much
greater importance than people currently appreciate.
Well, I enjoyed it very much.
Thank you for being with me.
Glad to be here.
And thank you for being with us.
